subject: Re: What's wrong with using inner classes for tests?
msgSnippet: ... I don t belive that to be true but maybe I m missing something. In the following code you can delete the Foo$Test.class file and the `java Foo` still works
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@f...> wrote:
> 1. Cannot deliver without tests, so your delivery is bloated

I don't belive that to be true but maybe I'm missing something. In the
following code you can delete the Foo$Test.class file and the `java
Foo` still works which means a `find src/ -name '*$Test.class' | xargs
rm ` would remove the test cases from your final product.

public class Foo {
Foo() {
System.out.println("Foo");
}
public static void main(String args[]) {
new Foo();
}

public static class Test {
Test() {
System.out.println("Foo.Test");
new Foo();
}
public static void main(String args[]) {
new Test();
}
}
}


> 2. Personally speaking, it clutters the class definition, making it
> more time consuming to navigate the file (yes, IDEs can help with
> this, but...)
I agree it's desireable to keep source files smaller.

> 3. Automated suite generation is more difficult
I have created a test ant build script with an junit task that matches
"*$Test".

> 4. Inner classes are member variables of the object;
Are static inner classes actually a member variable or just an
extension of the package namespace system. (I'm not sure if I'm
describing that correctly.)

> they usually do
> something for the object's functionality that the object doesn't
> want to do itself --> Are your tests really extensions/helpers to
> your object's functionality?
understood

> 5. Why not just put it in its own file? It's just as easy and not
> at all hard to keep in sync.
That's seperate from what I'm asking.

The inner class method keeps everything together which is appealing,
though it may not be logically consistant. I'm curious where it breaks
down negativly.
